Award.AbstractNarration:
Peter Pulay of the University of Arkansas is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to develop improved electronic structure methods for simulating reactions in solutions, with possible extension to a protein environment. Accurate simulation of these reactions requires the evaluation of thermodynamic averages, increasing the computational burden by many orders of magnitude. Pulay's recent General Polarizability Quantum Mechanics / Molecular Mechanics (GP-QM/MM) methodology has already been implemented in a Metropolis Monte Carlo code and shown to speed up conventional QM/MM calculations by four orders of magnitude with barely any sacrifice in accuracy. Pulay and his coworkers will develop analytical gradients for the new method, allowing the determination of reaction paths in solutions. They will also implement improved solvent models, to match the accuracy of the description of the reactive system. They will extend the current Monte Carlo simulations to the alternative Molecular Dynamics method which can supply information about the time scale of the changes. The new techniques will be applied to the prediction of pKa values, equilibria between zwitterionic and neutral forms of amino acids and small peptides, conformational preferences of peptides, and reactions known to be strongly affected by polar solvents. They will also investigate the factors determining whether anions preferentially adsorb on the surface in water microdroplets.

During the last three decades, both computer power and theoretical methods advanced tremendously, finally allowing accurate routine calculation of the electronic structures and properties of medium-sized chemical systems in the gas phase. However, most chemistry (and virtually all biochemistry) takes place in solution or in a protein environment. Polar solvents like water have a profound effect on chemical reactivity, and require very large numbers of simulation runs to obtain accurate averages. As a result, significant approximations are frequently made in the methods, although this reduces their accuracy. Instead, the methods under development in the Pulary group aim to correct this situation and have been shown to reduce the computational cost by 4 orders of magnitude; larger savings are expected for bigger systems. This will allow the use of accurate theoretical methods for solutions. Pulay has contributed a number of algorithmic advances in the field of electronic structure theory, beginning with the analytical gradient technique which is the cornerstone of most current quantum chemical applications. Other widely used contributions are molecular geometry optimization, acceleration of the basic method to calculate wavefunctions (SCF), the calculation of NMR chemical shifts, and Local Electron Correlation. Pulay and his coworkers also work on utilizing computer simulation of molecules to improve undergraduate and graduate chemistry education, using sophisticated computer graphics to convey the information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction

Almost everything around us is chemical matter. Chemistry is virtually inexhaustible, and therefore computer modeling of chemical phenomena is necessary for progress. The complexity of quantum mechanical equations precluded their solutions until recently. We can now predict the properties of medium-sized molecules accurately and efficiently. Two problems remain partly unsolved:

1 Modeling systems with many degrees of freedom, for instance solutions. The observable quantities here are averages of billions of microstates in which the solvent molecules are randomly arranged.

2 Strong electron correlation where some electrons partially occupy several orbitals. This is the case for most chemical reactions near the transition state, and in transition metal compounds. Standard electronic structure methods become inaccurate for such systems.

The main topic of this project is the simulation of solutions but the ultimate goal is the simulation of reactions in solutions, and thus both topics were addressed.

 

Quantum/Molecular Mechanics (QM/MM) simulations

Solutions are generally too big to simulate quantum mechanically. Even if a single configuration of, say, water molecules around a solute can be calculated, millions of calculations with random water configurations must be averaged to describe the macroscopic system. Fortunately, most solvents are simple, rigid molecules which interact with the solute through electrostatic and short range van der Waals forces. Most solvents can be simulated by a simple electrostatic plus mechanical model called Moleculoar Mechanics (MM). The whole system can be modeled by a quantum mechanical description of the solute and an MM solvent model, hence the name QM/MM. It cuts the computational cost for a single solvent configuration drastically. However, thermodynamic simulations which aim at free energies require 5-50 million configurations, making even QM/MM too expensive.

 

Ultrafast QM/MM

This method eliminates the need for quantum calculations for the solute which are the main expense in QM/MM. They are needed because the strong electric field of polar solvents like water distort the electronic structure of the solute. We expand the electric potential within the solute molecule in terms of predefined functions (we used plane waves, usually a few hundred to a few thousand suffice), and precalculate the response (polarization) of the solute by the components of the electric potential. This is a one-time expense. In the simulation phase, we use these responses to calculate the energy in the electric field of the solvent. This speeds up the calculations typically by about a factor of ten thousand. The accuracy does not suffer by this approximation, see Fig. 1 which shows the statistical deviation from a traditional QM/MM calculation for two cases: we neglect the deformation (polarization) of the solute (broad peak on the right, offset from zero by ~5 kcal/mol), and use our precalculated values (sharp peak, offset by only 0.08 kcal/mol).

Even with Ultrafast QM/MM, modeling multi-dimensional potential surfaces is too demanding if only energy values are used, a method called Free Energy Perturbation. The reason is than only very small steps can be made in the geometry of the solute without affecting the accuracy. To solve this, we have implemented the forces (negative gradients with respect to the coordinates of the solute atoms) which allow an alternative method, Thermodynamic Integration, or Potential of the Mean Force. This cuts the effort further by a factor of 10-20 for a one-dimensional reaction path, and by 100-400 for a 2-D surface.

We have applied our new techniques for the positional preference o9f halide ions in water nanodroplets, for SN2 reactions, and for mapping the conformational energies of a simple dipeptide model in water.

In the field of strong electron correlation, one problem is finding the orbitals with fractional occupation, the so-called active space. We have suggested long ago that the fractionally occupied natural orbitals of the Unrestricted Hartree-Fock wavefunction provide the correct active space. However, this could be fully verified only recently, with much more powerful computer and the new Density Matrix Renormalization Group method. The correct UHF solution itself is often difficult to find. We have found, partly accidentally, that a simple linear system of equations provides the solution.

The intellectual merit of this research is that it allows accurate and efficient simulations for solutions.  Most chemistry and all biochemistry takes place in solutions, and this will be the next phase of computer modeling of chemical systems. We see applications in biochemistry and also in materials chemistry. The second topic, strong correlation, is important for understanding chemical reactivity.
